turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Look at this!  The dog!  She's dead!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: She was old.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Old?!  Come look at this!  She has wounds.  Wounds on her head.  Like thrashes.  Or bites.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Maybe an animal.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: An animal?  What kind of animal? A goddamned T-Rex, or what?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Let me guess:  Another short circuit?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Hi, darling.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: During the Middle Ages people were executed at every corner.  What's your point?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: This house, the whole damned area around here is one mass grave... Now you might call me crazy, but there is something negative about the place.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Okay, so the house has a history and there might still be a couple of corpses in the moors.  "There is something negative about the place..."  What the hell are you trying to say?  Come on!  Spit it out!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Will you finally cut it out?  Just in case you haven't noticed, I am trying to write a book here.  And maybe - even with your birdbrains - you can figure it's a pretty tough job. So why can't you just leave me alone?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Damn it, look at you!  Don't you see what's happening with you?  We need to get out of here, don't you understand?  Out of this house!

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Martin, what-

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's simply too dangerous here! But no, you always have to have it your way.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You know what I have to do now, and believe me:  I don't enjoy doing this.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Martin, damnit, what are you up to? Let go of me!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Of course you'll give me the blame again.  Like back then.  Just a tiny cut and he could still be alive today - isn't that right, Ellen?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: What are you talking about-

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Oh, Ellen.  My sweet Ellen... Of course I knew.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: We loved each other once.  Have you forgotten that?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I told you, there is no way out. He won't let you go.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: 'HE'?  Whom do you mean-

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: It's important - he knows the last chapter.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Your book - that's why you were always in the cellar!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You know, Tommi wants me to become the man I used to be.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: ...So he's dictating you a new bestseller?  Whatever that is, it's not our son.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I have a yearning for... smog, cars and many, many people... A real dirty... big city. What do you think?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: How did you get me out of there?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: I wouldn't have made it by myself.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: For God's sake, what happened to me?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: You don't remember?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Ellen.

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: You're doing fine, aren't you?  I mean... the two of you alone in that house, so far out in the moor.

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: Oh, Ellen!  I've been wondering when you'd come.  Why don't you step in.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: I really hate to bother him, but...

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: Oh no, no.  You're not bothering him.  He has lots of time since he's been retired.

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: Frank Kosinski.  Here's the address.  Go see him.  Ask him.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Thank you.  Elisabeth, I didn't mean to...

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: That's alright.  Don't misunderstand my husband.  It's only that he's already had enough problems with this case. And who would believe him if he told the truth?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: But what is the truth?

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: I don't know all about what happened back then.  But it always stood between me and my husband.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Hello.  Can I help you?

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: Does this dog here belong to you?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: No, I've never seen him before.

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: You know, I saw him sitting outside your gate...  Oh, I'm sorry, I'm forgetting my manners again!  I haven't even introduced myself yet. Hi, my name's Lindner. Karl Lindner.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Ellen Straub.

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: It's a pleasure.  You're from the city, right?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Do I look like it that much?

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: Village gossip.  You're a real attraction here.

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: I guess it's too lonely for most folks.  It's time for me to get going. It's been a pleasure meeting you.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Wait, won't you join me for a cup of coffee?

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: You know, after doing that job for so many years, you learn to appreciate the simple things in life.  Flowers incorporate a beauty that I always missed in life.  But certainly, you're not here to chat about my hobbies.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: 1976.  What happened back then?

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: Do yourself a favor:  Don't ask.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: I appreciate your concern, but we live in that house.  I need to know what happened in there.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: Listen, it's one thing to have a guilt complex. But I know the difference between when I'm overstrung and when I'm seeing things that are simply not there! Besides, it only began after we moved!

turns.speaker: PROF. ROTH
turns.text: There is, of course, another possible explanation which I dearly hope is not the case.

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: And that is?

turns.speaker: PROF. ROTH
turns.text: A tumor - which could cause pressure on certain parts of the brain and, thus, influence your perception.

turns.speaker: PROF. ROTH
turns.text: Mrs. Straub!

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: I've killed my husband!

turns.speaker: PROF. ROTH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: I think I've killed him.  Martin, my husband, I've killed him!  That is, I'm not sure, but...

turns.speaker: ELLEN
turns.text: It all went so fast.  He was out of his mind and then all of sudden there was this screwdriver.  I only wanted to defend myself.  You have to call the police...

turns.speaker: PROF. ROTH
turns.text: We can do all of that later, but first you need to calm down.

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: Oh, Mrs. Straub.  May I introduce you to my wife?

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: Just call me Elisabeth.

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: Stop scaring people.  Let's go. We need to be on our way.

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: Excuse us.  But do stop by for a visit sometime!  You are welcome anytime.

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: You didn't tell her!

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: We should leave the past alone.

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: Well, it will never leave us alone as long as you ignore it.

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: I think it's starting again. You know... there was something peculiar.  If only I knew...

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: Peculiar?  You mean, like back then?

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: Yes, something was...

turns.speaker: MRS. LINDNER
turns.text: Hammer?

turns.speaker: LINDNER
turns.text: How could I fail to notice that! - I have to go...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, look here!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Ladies and gentlemen: The "Straub country-residence".

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Damn, this thing is heavy. Where do you want to have it?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Tenth floor.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Very funny.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Look at this.  The lock is totally demolished.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I guess someone lost their key. You did get your tetanus shots, I hope?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Twenty-three, to be exact.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I wonder how you guys figure on renovating this whole place.  You can afford to spend some money.  If I was you, I'd spare myself all the hard work.  Besides, didn't you want to start writing again?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hey, my man!  How's the masterpiece coming along?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Not so bad, if I could get some peace and quiet around here.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: We are in desperate want of a Mercutio, Ned, a young nobleman of Verona

turns.speaker: ALLEYN
turns.text: And the title of this piece?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Mercutio

turns.speaker: ALLEYN
turns.text: WillWhere is Mercutio?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Locked safe in here. I leave the scene in your safe keeping, Ned, I have a sonnet to write.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You did not like the speech?

turns.speaker: ALLEYN
turns.text: The speech is excellent.  "Oh, then I see Queen Mab hath been with you!" Excellent and a good length. But then he disappears for the length of a bible.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: NedI knowI know

turns.speaker: ALLEYN
turns.text: It's good.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh

turns.speaker: ALLEYN
turns.text: The title won't do.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Ah

turns.speaker: ALLEYN
turns.text: Romeo and Juliet--just a suggestion.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Thank you, Ned.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You are a gentleman.

turns.speaker: ALLEYN
turns.text: And you are a Warwickshire shit-house.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Ohwhat have I done?

turns.speaker: ALLEYN
turns.text: He was the first man among us. A great light has gone out.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Follow that boat!

turns.speaker: BOATMAN
turns.text: Right you are, governor!

turns.speaker: BOATMAN
turns.text: I know your face. Are you an actor?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BOATMAN
turns.text: Yes, I've seen you in something. That one about a king.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: BOATMAN
turns.text: I had the Christopher Marlowe in my boat once.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Do you know that house?

turns.speaker: BOATMAN
turns.text: Sir Robert De Lesseps.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, Thomas! She has cut my strings! I am unmanned, unmended, and unmade, like a puppet in a box.

turns.speaker: BOATMAN
turns.text: Writer, is he?

turns.speaker: BOATMAN
turns.text: Thank you, my lady!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Lady?

turns.speaker: BOATMAN
turns.text: Viola De Lesseps. Known her since she was this high. Wouldn't deceive a child.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: What do you want, Kit?

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: My Massacre at Paris is complete.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: You have the last act?

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: You have the money?

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: Tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: Then tomorrow you will have the pages.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: Wait!  Will you desist!

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: Twenty pounds on delivery

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: What is money to me like us? Besides, if I need a play, I have another waiting, a comedy by Shakespeare.

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: Romeo?--he gave it to Henslowe.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: Never!

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: Well, I am to Deptford now, I leave my respects, Miss Rosaline.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: I gave Shakespeare two sovereigns for Romeo!

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: You did. But Ned Alleyn and the Admiral's Men have the playing of it as the Rose.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: Treachery!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Burbage, I will see you hanged for a pickpocket.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: The Queen has commanded, she loves a comedy and the Master of the Revels favours us.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: And what favour does Mr. Tilney receive from you?

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: Ask him.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: We have no Juliet!

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: No Juliet?!

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: We will all be put in the clink.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: See you in jail.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: There is no dog in the first scene, Will Kempe, thank you. How goes it Will?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I am still owed money for this play, Burbage.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: Not from me. I only stole it. When are you coming over to the Chamberlain's Men?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: When I have fifty pounds.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: Are you writing?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: A comedy. All but done, a pirate comedy, wonderful.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: What is the chief part?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Romeo. Wit, swordsman, lover.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: The title?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Romeo

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: I will play him. Bring it tomorrow.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It's for Henslowe. He paid me.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Ten pounds.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: You're a liar.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I swear it. He wants Romeo for Ned and the Admiral's Men.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: Ned is wrong for it.

turns.speaker: BURBAGE
turns.text: Here is two sovereigns--I'll give you two more when you show me the pages.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Done.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Words, words, wordsonce, I had the giftI could make love out of words as a potter makes cups out of clay love that overthrows empires, love that binds two hearts together come hellfire and brimstonesfor sixpence a line, I could cause a riot in a nunnerybut now

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: And yet you tell me you lie with women?

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: Black Sue, Fat Phoebe, Rosaline, Burbage's seamstress; Aphrodite, who does it behind the Dog and

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Aye, now and again, but what of it? I have lost my gift.

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: I am here to help you. Tell me in your own words.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I have lost my gift.  It's as if my quill is broken. As if the organ of the imagination has dried up. As if the proud tower of my genius has collapsed.

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: Interesting.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Nothing comes.

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: Most interesting.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It is like trying to a pick a lock with a wet herring.

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: Tell me, are you lately humbled in the act of love?

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: How long has it been?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: A goodly length in times past, but lately

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: No, no. You have a wife, children

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: A woman of property?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: She had a cottage. One day, she was three months gone with child, so

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: And your relations?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: On my mother's side the Ardens

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: No, your marriage bed.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Four years and a hundred miles away in Stratford. A cold bed too, since the twins were born. Banishment was a blessing.

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: So now you are free to love

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: yet cannot love nor write it.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Will it restore my gift?

turns.speaker: DR. MOTH
turns.text: The woman who wears the snake will dream of you, and your gift will return. Words will flow like a river. I will see you in a week.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Gentlemen! Thank you! You are welcome.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Who is that?

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: I saw his Tamburlaine, you know. Wonderful.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yes, I saw it.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Of course, it was mighty writing. There is no one like Marlowe

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Mr. Fennyman, because you love the theatre you must have a part in my play. I am writing an Apothecary, a small but vital role.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: By heaven, I thank you! I will be your Apothecary!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I have not said all. By malign fate, the message goes astray which would tell Romeo of the Friar's plan. He hears only that Juliet is dead. And thus he goes to the Apothecary.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: That's me.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: And buys a deadly poison. He enters the tomb to say farewell to Juliet who lies there cold as death. He drinks the poison. He dies by her side. And then she wakes and sees him dead.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Two weeks, three at the most, Aaaagh! For pity's sake.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Take his feet out. Where will you get

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: I have a wonderful new play!

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Put his feet in.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: It's a comedy.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Cut his nose off.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: A new comedy. By Will Shakespeare!

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: And his ears.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: And a share. We will be partners, Mr. Fennyman!

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Partners!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: It's a crowd-tickler--mistaken identities, a shipwreck, a pirate king, a bit with a dog, and love triumphant.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: What's the title?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Good title.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: But I have to pay the actors and the authors.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: A share of the profits.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: There's never any

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Of course not!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Mr. Fennyman, I think you may have hit on something.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Romeo and Ethel The Pirate's DaughterAlmost finished?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Without doubt he is completing it at this very moment.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: This time we take your boots off!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: What have I done, Mr. Fennyman?

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: The theatres are all closed by the plague!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Oh, that.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: by order of the Master of the Revels!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Mr. Fennyman, let me explain about the theatre business.  The natural condition is one of insurmountable obstacles on the road to imminent disaster. Believe me, to be close by the plague is a bagatelle in the ups and downs of owning a theatre.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: So what do we do?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Nothing. Strangely enough , it all turns out well.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: I don't know. It's a mystery.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Where is the play?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Oh, it's coming, it's coming.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Is it going well?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Very well.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: But nothing is happening.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Yes, but very well.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: I want no more trouble, Mr. Fennyman. As I explained to you, the theatre business

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Henslowe, you pound of tripe, in my business I would be out of business if I had your courage, so don't tell me about business

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Mr. Shakespeare has given me the part of the Apothecary!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: The Apothecary? Will, what is the story? Where is the shipwreck? How does the comedy end?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Well, that will have them rolling in the aisles.

turns.speaker: FENNYMAN
turns.text: Sad and wonderful! I have a blue velvet cap which will do well, I have seen apothecary with a cap just so.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Ned, I swear I knew nothing of this!

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Nobody knew!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: It is over.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: I am so sorry, Mr. Henslowe. I wanted to be an actor.  I am sorry, Will.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: No Juliet?!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: it will be all right, madam.

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: What happened to Sam?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Thomas Kent!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Do you know it?

turns.speaker: VIOLA
turns.text: Every word.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Will! Where is my play? Tell me you have it nearly done! Tell me you have it started.  You have begun?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Doubt that the stars are fire, doubt that the sun doth move

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: No, no, we haven't the time. Talk prose. Where is my play?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It is all locked safe in here

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: God be praised!  Locked?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: As soon as I have found my muse

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Who is she this time?!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: She is always Aphrodite.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Aphrodite Baggot who does it behind the Dog and Trumpet?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Henslowe, you have no soul so how can you understand the emptiness that seeks a soulmate?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Well, I am a dead man and buggered to boot. My theatre is close by the plague these twelve weeks, my company is playing the inn-yards of England, while Burbage and the Chamberlain's Men are invited to court and receive ten pounds to play your piece, written for my theatre, by my writer, at my risk when you were green and grateful -

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What piece? Richard Crookback?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: No--it's comedy they want, Will! Comedy! Like Romeo and Ethel?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Who wrote that?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Nobody! You are writing it for me! I gave you three pounds a month since.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Half what you owed me. I am still due for One Gentleman of Verona.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Mr. Henslowe, will you lend me fifty pounds?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Fifty pounds? What for?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Burbage offers me a partnership in the Chamberlain's Men. For fifty pounds my hired player days are over.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Cut out my heart! Throw my liver to the dogs!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No, then.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: To my weekly confession.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Now where? Will?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: To the Palace at Whitehall.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I feel a scene coming on.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Is it about a pirate's daughter?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Romeo and Rosaline. Scene One! God, I'm good!

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Rosaline? You mean Ethel.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Will! Have you finished?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yes. Nearly.  It's all locked safe in here. We need Ralph for the Pirate King. Good morning, Master Nol. You will have a nice little part.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: My tailor. Wants to be an actor. I have a few debts here and there. Well, that seems to be everybody. Did you see a Romeo?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I did not.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Well, I to my work, you to yours. When can I see pages?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Tomorrow

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: We are at least six men short, and those we have will be overparted, ranters and stutterers who should be sent back to the stews. My Romeo has let me down. I see disaster.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: We are at least four acts short, Will, if you are looking for disaster.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Nobody. The author.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: We are about to embark on a great voyage.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: It is customary to make a little speech on the first day. It does no harm and authors like it.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You want to know what parts you are to receive. All will be settled as we go

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Cut round him for now.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: What? Who?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Romeo.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: The one who came with your letter?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Juliet? You mean Ethel.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: God's teeth, am I to suffer this constant stream of interruption?!  What will you do in Act Two when he meets the love of his life?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: By God, I wish I knew.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: By God, Will, if you do not, who does? Let us have pirates, clowns, and a happy ending, or we will send you back to Stratford to your wife!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: We are lost.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: No, it will turn out well.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: How will it?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: I don't know, it's a mystery.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Another little problem.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What do we do now?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: The show must  you know

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: Juliet does not come on for twenty pages. It will be all right.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: How will it?

turns.speaker: HENSLOWE
turns.text: I don't know. It's a mystery.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Kit

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: How goes it, Will?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Wonderful, wonderful.

turns.speaker: MARLOWE
turns.text: Burbage says you have a play.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I have. And chinks to show for it.
